[9]I got involved. And I cared. 
[10]And I think I made a difference. 
[11]I knew I touched the students' lives during their difficult young adult years, and I took that responsibility seriously. 
[12]In the twelve years I taught U.S. History, Civics and current Events at Millard, I was voted Teacher of the Year three times - a school record. 
[13]Standing in front of a room full of young people, trying to make them think that's how I wanted to spend the rest of my life,

[21]Tracy. 
[22]Tracy Flick.  Tracy Flick.  I've never met anyone quite like Tracy Flick. 
[23]She first showed up in my life as a freshman delegate in student council. I'd seen a lot of ambitious students come and go over the years, but I could tell right away Tracy Flick was different. 
[24]It wasn't long before everyone knew who Tracy Flick was.  She made sure of that. Her drive was astonishing.  Even scary. 
[25]Now at the end of her junior year, Tracy was poised to win the presidency of the student body.  And so far she was running unopposed. 
[26]Oh.  There's one more thing about Tracy I think you should know. 
[27]A few months before the election, she'd had an affair with my best friend Dave Novotny. 
[28]Don't tell me that.  I don't want to know that. 
[29]Dave came to Millard the year after I did, and we hit it off right away. We backed each other up in teachers' meetings and shared an interest in 60's music and micro-breweries. 
[30]You could tell Dave was one of those guys who taught because they never wanted to leave high school in the first place, and that could get a little irritating sometimes, but basically he was a real good guy. 
[31]Our wives became best friends too. And when Dave and Sherry's son Darryl was born, they asked us to be godparents. 
[32]You did it at your house?  Your own house? 
[33]In love? 
[34]But you haven't written your novel.

[36]That was just talk!  Fantasy talk! What are you, nuts?  We talk about girls all the time, but it doesn't mean anything. I would never. . . I mean, I take very seriously our strict moral code.  The line you've crossed is... it's illegal and it's immoral. 
[37]I'm not talking about ethics.  I'm talking about morals. 
[38]I guess I don't have to tell you how all this turned out.

I really, really need you now."  The booklet is lowered.

[71]Exactly.  So what do you say?  Maybe it's time to give a little something back.

But someday maybe you'll learn that being smart and always being on top and doing whatever you need to do to get ahead, and yes, stepping on people to get there, well, there's a lot more to life than that.  And in the end, you're only cheating yourself.

I think the lesson there is that, old and young, we ail make mistakes, and we have to learn that our actions, all of them, can carry serious consequences.  You're very young, Tracy underage, in fact -- but maybe one day you'll understand.

[160]As I walked out of my home that evening, unsure if I'd ever return, my entire life in question, I somehow discovered within myself a place of perfect peace.   Oddly, in my solitude I felt more than ever a sense of communion with every human being - past, present and future.  Because no matter what we tell ourselves, no matter what illusions of friendship and family we create, each of us is always and forever profoundly alone. 
[161]Sherry never came home that night.  I know, because I spent the entire night in her driveway. 
[162]I had no choice but to go home. I needed to shower, get fresh clothes, explain what I could to Diane.  But what was I going to say?  That our marriage had become a charade?  That making love with Sherry had given me a vision of a better life?

I just think we should talk, okay?  I love you.

[187]The sight of Tracy at that moment affected me in a way I can't fully explain.  Part of it was that she was spying, but mostly it was her face. Looking at her, you might think she was a sweet, innocent teenage girl. But she wasn't sweet.  And she wasn't innocent. She was selfish and cynical and ambitious and thought nothing of destroying the lives of others to get to the top. who knew how high she would climb in life, how many people would suffer because of her? [212]I don't know how Diane and I made it through that night, but we did.  Our marriage had gone right to the brink, but in the end I guess it was saved by one simple fact: we truly loved each other.  So we made a commitment to begin the painful process of piecing our lives back together.  The worst was over; the mistakes of the past were behind us. 
[213]The next day held the promise of a new beginning. After all, what harm had really been done? No one was dead.

[219]After Paul got the bad news, Walt asked for a few minutes alone with me. It was very simple, really. I offered my resignation, and he accepted. Very quietly, it was all over for JIM McAllister at Millard High - twelve years of hard work down the drain. 
[220]Walt will be speaking with you about this, but I need you to find someone to take over my classes. The lesson plans for the rest of the year are in my top right drawer. 
[221]Thanks. Well. I'm going home now. 
[222]I don't remember driving home, or much of anything that happened in the next few days. 
[223]There were news stories in the paper and on television, former students calling with their support, endless hours of doing nothing, thinking nothing. 
[224]Diane stood by me through the entire humiliating ordeal, in a way, it sort of evened things out between us. 
[225]Soon school was over, and summer stretched out in front of me as it always had. Funny how the rhythm of the school year remains ingrained in you for life. in mid-June we found out Diane was pregnant. 
[226]After two months of sitting on my ass and two months helping out at my brother-in-law's travel agency... 
[227]...I landed a position at a Saturn dealership. 
[228]I never thought I'd end up selling cars, but it's not so bad. I like the Saturn philosophy -- it really is a different kind of company. 
[229]I'm just relieved to have a steady income now that there are three of us. 
[230]Actually, it wasn't so difficult making the transition from teaching to selling. It's like I tell my customers: my role is just to educate people so they can make informed decisions. 
[231]When I send someone home with a new unit, I feel a genuine sense of pride. 
[232]So that's about it.  Maybe I'll get back to teaching someday, but for the time being, I guess I'm pretty happy where I'm at.

dialogues.TRACY:
[1]None of this would have happened if Mr. McAllister hadn't meddled the way he did.  He should have just accepted things as they are instead of trying to interfere with destiny.  You see, you can't interfere with destiny.  That's why it's destiny.  And if you try to interfere, the same thing's going to happen anyway, and you'll just suffer. 
[2]Good morning, Mr. McAllister. 
[3]You know what they say about the early bird. 
[4]Thanks, Mr. M. 
[5]No matter what he says, Mr. McAllister had it out for me from the start.  Oh sure, he was all smiles and good wishes and everything, but underneath he was just as unfair and petty as anybody else. 
[6]He'll probably tell you how committed he was to teaching and democracy and integrity and all. Don't be fooled. 
[7]I know. 
[8]Ethics are... 
[9]Some people say I'm an overachiever, but I think they're just jealous. 
[10]My Mom always tells me I'm different -- you know, special. And if you look at all the things I've accomplished so far, I think you'd have to agree. 
[11]Here I am in Oklahoma. 
[12]I'm just a girl who can't say no... 
[13]And here I am on KMHS, our student-run TV station. 
[14]..that's why Principal Hendricks made the controversial announcement that the littering must stop.  Tracy Flick reporting. 
[15]But it was in SGA, the Student Government Association, where I made my biggest mark.  I never missed a meeting, and I volunteered for every committee as long as I could lead it. 
[16]I agree with Ashley.  We should rent the barrels at least a day beforehand. What happened last time was a travesty, I mean, we were -- 
[17]...the rules of conduct determined by a culture at a... 
[18]YOU probably think the worst - that Mr. Novotny was just taking advantage of one of his students, but it wasn't like that at all. Our relationship was based on mutual respect and admiration. I mean, during my sophomore year in geometry it was strictly professional between us -- I mean, nothing. 
[19]It wasn't until junior year when we worked together on the yearbook that things got serious. 
[20]One night he took us editors out to celebrate after a deadline. Eventually Dave and I were left alone and we got to talking - not like teacher and student, but like two adults. 
[21]what? 
[22]No, I'm not. I'm just really busy. 
[23]What do you mean? What kind of person am I? 
[24]Thank you. 
[25]Since I grew up without a dad, you might assume psychologically I was looking for a father figure. 
[26]But that had nothing to do with it at all.  It was just that Dave was so strong and made me feel so safe and protected. 
[27]It was the first time somebody ever saw the real me, the me that nobody else knows. 
[28]When I think back on my relationship with Mr. Novotny, what I miss most. is our talks. 
[29]...certain time in history and 
[30]Now that I have more life experience, I feel sorry for Mr. McAllister. 
[31]I mean, anyone who's stuck in the same little room saying the exact same things year after year for his whole life, wearing the same stupid clothes, while his students go on to good colleges and move to big cities and do great things and make loads of money has got to be at least a little jealous.  It's like my room says - the weak always try to sabotage the strong. 
[32]One thing that's important to know about me is that I'm an only child.  So my Mom is really devoted to me, and I love her so much.  She wants me to do all the things she wanted to do in life but couldn't. 
[33]See, Mom used to be a stewardess for Northwest and now works as a para-legal. She likes to write letters to successful women like Janet Reno and Elizabeth Dole and ask them how they got to be where they are and what advice do they have for me, Tracy, her daughter. 
[34]Nine times out of ten they say you have to hold on to your dreams no matter what.  The pressures women face mean you have to work twice as hard, and you can't let anything or anyone stand in your way. 
[35]One per person!  Put those back I 
[36]Ninety-seven.. .ninety-eight. 
[37]But you know,  winning isn't everything.  If you play fair and follow all the rules thoroughly, you'll always come out ahead.  Win or lose, ethical conduct is the most important thing. Just ask Mr. McAllister. 
[38]Mr. McAllister? Mr. McAllister! Wait up 
[39]I got all my signatures.  One hundred and fifty-eight -- way more than I need! 
[40]Here they are. 
[41]Could you approve them now?  I'd like to kick off my campaign right away, you know, in the morning. 
[42]Aren't you supposed to keep them? 
[43]I thought you were supposed to keep them. 
[44]Thanks for everything. 
[45]I can't wait to start campaigning. 
[46]Hell, you know, Coca-Cola's the world's number one soft drink, but they spend more money than anybody on advertising. I guess that's how come they stay number one. 
[47]You know, Mr. M., when I win the presidency, that means you and I are going to be spending a lot of time together next year.  And I for one would like that time to be harmonious and productive. Wouldn't you? 
[48]Okay. That's good. I just wanted to make sure. 
[49]...harmonious and productive... close and special... you and I...  so close... so intimate... together... 
[50]The right side is too high. The right side. Just a smidge. 
[51]Who put you up to this? 
[52]Who put you up to this? 
[53]You just woke up this morning and suddenly decided to run for president? 
[54]Thought what? 
[55]So Mr. McAllister asked you to run. 
[56]Okay, Mr. Popular.  You're on. 
[57]You might think it upset me that Paul Metzier had decided to run against me, but nothing could be further from the truth.  He was no competition for me: it was like apples and oranges. It just meant I had to work a little harder, that's all. 
[58]You see, I believe in the voters. They understand that elections aren't just popularity contests. They know this country was built by people just like me who work very hard and don't have everything handed to them on a silver spoon. 
[59]Not like some rich kids who everybody likes because their fathers own Metzier Cement and give them trucks on their sixteenth birthday and throw them big parties all the time.  They don't ever have to work for anything. 
[60]They think they can all of a sudden one day out of the blue waltz right in with no qualifications whatsoever and try to take away what other people have worked for very, very hard their entire lives. No, it didn't bother me at all I 
[61]Fuck me, Mr. McAllister 
[62]You're the advisor.  You should stop her.  She's not qualified.  She's just a sophomore. 
[63]Are you sure all her signatures are real?  It's not easy to get all those signatures. 
[64]Let me see them.  Let me see them 
[65]These are a bunch of burn-outs. And look at this one, I can't even read this one. 
[66]Tim Kobza?  Tim Kobza!  Who's he? I've never heard of him! 
[67]Poet Henry David Thoreau once wrote, "I cannot make my days longer, so I strive to make them better."  With this election, we here at Millard also have an opportunity to make our high school days better.  During this campaign I have had the opportunity to speak with many of you about your concerns.  I spoke with freshman Eliza Ramirez, who told me how alienated she feels from her own homeroom.  I spoke with sophomore Reggie Banks, who said his mother works in a cafeteria and can't afford to buy him enough spiral notebooks for his classes.  I won't bore you with long- winded promises about all the new and innovative things I will definitely achieve during the year in which it will be my honor and privilege to represent each and every one of you, but I can say that my years of experience on the student council have taught me the three most important attributes the president needs to possess;  commitment - 
[68]The three most important attributes the president needs to possess are: commitment, qualifications, and experience.  I'll add one more; caring. I care about Millard, and I care about each and every one of you, and together we can all make a difference.  One of the things I would like to establish is a regular open forum where any student can come and voice their concern about issues we face here at Millard.  I and the rest of the student council would then interface with the faculty and staff, so a continuous dialogue would exist. 
[69]When you cast your vote for Tracy Flick next week, you won't just be voting for me.  You'll be voting for yourself and for every other student Our days won't be any longer, but they can sure be better.  Thank you. 
[70]What happened at the speeches was an unconscienceable travesty. That little bitch Tammy Metzier wanted to make a fool out of me. Well, it wasn't going to work. People do care who wins. Things do matter. 
[71]Eric, the "r" is supposed to be green, not blue. 
[72]That's okay.  I'm too busy. 
[73]People are so ungrateful.  If all those students who cheered for Tammy Metzier only knew how hard I worked for Millard. Like all the late nights I spent at the yearbook office just to give them their memories. 
[74]One of my duties was to clean up the group photos.  It was a cinch with our new software. 
[75]Let's see... "save" is Command "S." Okay. 
[76]I didn't do this.  I didn't do it. 
[77]When I arrived at school that morning, I was shocked to find that one of my key banners had been removed by vandals. I noticed that a few of my rival's posters had also been tampered with. Of course, I was outraged, but one day before the election is not the time to lose your head over a couple of posters. When you're in the public eye, attacks like that just come with the territory. 
[78]If it's about the posters, I think it's so awful. It's a travesty. 
[79]Wait - are you accusing me? You're not serious. I can't... Mr. McAllister, we have worked together on SGA for three solid years and... I mean, I can't believe it. I'm... I'm shocked! 
[80]Mr. M., I am running on my qualifications.  I would never need to resort to, you know, to vandalism like a, you know... Plus, my own best banner was torn down.  Did I do that too? 
[81]I was.  So?  Mr. Pecharda let me in. As you know, with all my responsibilities I often come in on the weekend and have permission to do so. But I left very early, around 6:30. 
[82]I don't.  I just know they were there when I left.  I'm giving you helpful information is all.  You know, instead of wasting time interrogating me, we should be out there trying to find out who did this. 
[83]well, I don't know.  It could have been anybody.  There are a lot of, you know, subversive elements around Millard.  You know, like Rick Thieson and Kevin Speck and those burn-outs.  Or Doug Schenken - what about him?  Or what about Tammy Metzier?  Her whole thing is being anti- this and anti-that. 
[84]Why are you lecturing me? 
[85]I don't know what you're referring to, but I do know that if certain older and wiser people hadn't acted like such little babies and gotten all mushy, everything would be okay. 
[86]And I think certain older persons like you and your "colleague" shouldn't be leaching after their students, especially when some of them can't even get their own wives pregnant.  And they certainly shouldn't be running around making slanderous accusations. Especially when certain young, naive people's mothers are para-legal secretaries at the city's biggest law firm and have won many successful lawsuits. And if you want to keep questioning me like this, I won't continue without my attorney present. 
[87]This ought to be good 
[88]Yes? 
[89]What do you mean? 
[90]I told you!  I told you! You're going to pay for my banner! 
[91]Dear Lord Jesus, I do not often speak with You and ask for things, but now I really must insist that You help me win the election tomorrow, because I deserve it and Paul Metzier doesn't, as You well know.  l realize that it was Your divine hand that disqualified Tammy, and now I'm asking that You go that one last mile and make sure to put me in office where I belong, so that I may carry out Your will on Earth as it is in Heaven. If elected I promise that I will pray more often.  Okay?  Amen. 
[92]Mom and I got up at five AM, and together we custom-iced three hundred and fifty cupcakes. 
[93]I remember she was so happy, like there was nothing in the world she'd rather be doing.  Besides me and her job, I guess my mom doesn't have much of a life.  She hasn't dated anyone since Frank, and she hardly ever buys new clothes for herself or travels.  
[94]Mom? 
[95]I think I'm going to lose today 
[96]You really think so? 
[97]Good morning, Mr. M. 
[98]Looks like you could use a cupcake! 
[99]What's wrong with your eye?  Are you 
[100]When the time came to cast our votes, I stood in line just like everyone else. 
[101]Tracy Enid Flick. 
[102]Phil you ready? 
[103]Just wait. 
[104]Thanks, Phil. 
[105]Yeah. 
[106]Good luck to you too, Paul. 
[107]You know that moment when they announce the winner of a beauty pageant?  When Miss Texas or whoever suddenly realizes she's Miss America, and all she can do is scream and weep and hug the losers? I had my moment in the hallway that Tuesday afternoon with no one to hug but myself. 
[108]Paul, I just want you to know that no matter how this turns out, you've run a wonderful campaign. It's been fun competing with you. 
[109]Yeah. 
[110]Act surprised. Walk slowly to the podium.  Be modest.  Thank them for this incredible honor. 
[111]One vote... one vote 
[112]Senior year was very productive for me and full of personal achievement. 
[113]Order.  Order.  Order I  Can we vote on this?  Those in favor. 
[114]On top of a very successful student council year, I got into Cornell like I wanted, with scholarships, and I was in the top 7th percentile of my graduating class. 
[115]But sometimes I got lonely, and I'd think about Dave.  I missed our talks. Maybe it could have worked out between us.  I don't know. 
[116]I wonder what he's doing now. Maybe he finally finished his novel 
[117]When the yearbooks came out, I was on almost every page. 
[118]Paul, will you sign my yearbook? 
[119]Can I sign yours too? 
[120]I thought very carefully about what to write.  Because despite everything that had happened with the election, I really wished him well.  I even signed it... 
[121]Yes, Paul? 
[122]Thanks.  You too.  It was great working with you. 
[123]After graduation, I don't know.  ; somehow felt empty inside.  I guess high school just seemed so meaningless now and I couldn't wait to get out of Omaha. Next year I was going to make all new friends.  Smarter, more ambitious friends.  It was time to move on. There was nothing left for roe here.  I just had one more thing to take care of. 
[124]Hello, Mr. M. 
[125]I'm looking at new cars. 
[126]My mother's buying me a new car for college. 
[127]Well, I got in everywhere I applied, but Cornell is my first choice. 
[128]Sporty. 
[129]Where to? 
[130]Yeah. 
[131]Uh-huh. 
[132]That sounds good. 
[133]Yes? 
[134]Doing what? 
[135]Nooo.  I just thought...  l mean, I am looking for a new car.  But I just thought, well, I'm going away soon, and you'll be stuck here and, I don't know, I just think maybe if things had been different we might have been, well, friends. Real friends.  And then things would be different.  Don't you think? 
[136]I've got an idea. 
[137]My house. 
[138]I want you to do something for me. 
[139]I just have to get something. I'll be right back. 
[140]Would you sign it for me? 
[141]Take as much room as you want 
[142]I'm scared, Mr. M. I kind of don't feel ready for college. 
[143]I hope so
dialogues.PAUL:
[1]Stop daydreaming! Get back to work! 
[2]Why. . . ? Why. . . ? 
[3]I was so mad at God when I broke my leg at Shadow Ridge over Christmas break. 
[4]The doctors told me I'd have to quit sports for at least a couple years if not forever. 
[5]...which meant no first-string quarterback in the fall. It was like the end of my life! 
[6]When I got back to school everybody was so supportive, and they all wanted to sign my cast and everything... 
[7]... but I still couldn't shake the feeling that now my life had no purpose. What did God want from me? 
[8]Why did I exist? 
[9]Sometimes you can search everywhere for answers. Then one day destiny just taps you on the shoulder. I know, because it happened to me. 
[10]Mr. McAllister changed my life. And no matter what they say he did or did not do, I believe he is a good man. 
[11]I wanted to play next year so bad I could taste it.  And maybe go on to... 
[12]Yeah. 
[13]What do you mean? 
[14]Who, me?  Nooo.  I never... I don't know anything about that stuff, Mr. M. Besides, that's Tracy Flick's thing. She's always working so hard and -- 
[15]And she's super-nice 
[16]Huh?  Oh.  Uh... pears 
[17]No, wait -- apples.  Apples. 
[18]I also like bananas. 
[19]I gotta talk to him first. 
[20]Huh?  Oh, hi, Tracy 
[21]What do you mean? 
[22]No.  Uh... I just... you know, I just thought -- 
[23]Well, see, I was talking to Mr. McAllister about my leg and everything... and how I still want to, you know, do something for the school and -- 
[24]Well, I mean, you know, I talked to him and everything, but he just said he thought it was a good idea... and how there's all different kinds of fruit and...  It's nothing against you, Tracy. You're the best.  I just thought -- 
[25]Paul... Paul... power... Paul... Paul for President... progress... promise... peanut... Paul-i-tics... yeah... President Paul... Punt for Paul!  No. 
[26]Hey, Tammy, guess what happened today. 
[27]Yeah.  So guess what happened.  So Mr. McAllister, he -- Oh hi. Lisa. 
[28]So Mr. M. calls me in and tells me -- 
[29]What'd I do? 
[30]I sure was surprised the day Lisa Flanagan asked me for a ride home and ended up blowing me. 
[31]Uhhh... teeth. Teeth. 
[32]Life is so weird.  First Lisa has a big fight with my sister, and the next thing you know she's my girlfriend. 
[33]Since Lisa knew all about public relations and stuff, she offered to help me with my campaign.  We made a great team! 
[34]It seemed so natural, the two of us together.  It was like destiny. 
[35]That spring was perfect.  My leg wasn't bugging me too much, and the weather was so nice.  And every afternoon after school. Lisa and I would go to her house to fuck and have a swim.  It was like we were in a world all our own. 
[36]Tammy? Tammy, what are you doing? 
[37]We can't both run, can we?  We're brother and sister.  Can we? 
[38]For what? 
[39]For what? 
[40]As many of you know I broke my leg pretty bad thi3 year and the experience has made me reevaluate what I want to do with my life and that is help people when you think about it a school is more than a school it's our second home where we spend all cur time and grow as individuals and a community but is our school everything it could be I want our school to reach its true potential that is why I am running for president. 
[41]I know what it is to fight hard and win like when we almost went to state last fall and I threw that fourth-quarter pass against Westside for the touchdown that won the game by three points I won't let you down like I didn't then I promise we can all score a winning touchdown together. Vote Paul Metzier for president thank you. 
[42]Oh.  Hi, Tammy.  I was just, you know, I went to all your teachers and got your assignments. 
[43]I just thought, well, last time you got suspended you fell so behind and - 
[44]Yeah.  Oh, one more thing. Tammy. You know, all this election stuff. 'Cause, you know, everyone is saying it's so weird that you're running against me, and, well, it is kind of weird, and you haven't really told me why you're doing it and didn't tell me in advance or anything.  But that's okay, you know.  l respect your privacy.  I just want you to know that no matter who wins, if it's you or me, there's no hard feelings. We're still brother and sister.  Okay? Cause... and I hope you feel the same. 
[45]Okay.  Great.  I feel good. 
[46]Oh.  Oh.  Yeah.  Right.  One other thing.  Since you know Lisa so well, could you give me some advice?  I want to get her something for helping me with the election.  You know, something really special -- like flowers or candy or flowers and candy.  Or is that too typical?  I mean, can you think of something? Something really special? You know, something she'd really like? 
[47]I just don't think anybody would do something like that on purpose.  It must have been some kind of mistake. Like a maintenance thing. 
[48]We still have some extra ones, don't we?  Maybe we can just -- 
[49]Oh, no, hey.  Like I said. Tammy wouldn't... she... 
[50]Dear God, thank You for all Your blessings.  You have given me so many things, like good health, nice parents, a nice truck, and what I've been told is a large penis, and I'm very grateful. But I sure am worried about Tammy.  In my heart I still can't believe she tore down my posters, but sometimes she does get so weird and angry.  Please help her be a happier person, because she's so smart and sensitive, and I love her. Also, I'm nervous about the election tomorrow, and I guess I want to win and all, but I know that's totally up to You.  You'll decide who the best person is, and I'll accept it.  And forgive my sins, whatever they may be.  Amen. 
[51]Way to go, Tracy!  Isn't this exciting? 
[52]Hell, good luck! 
[53]Thanks! 
[54]It's so weird.  DO people always just vote for themselves?  'Cause looking at my own name on the ballot, I just... I don't know, I just felt like it's not right to vote for yourself. 
[55]Hey, Mr. M. Big day, huh? 
[56]Yeah, you too, Tracy.  I'm just glad it's over. 
[57]You know, I don't understand why everybody bad-mouthed Tracy all the time.  She was always super- nice to me. 
[58]Geez, you guys, thanks a lot.  I mean, wow, thanks.  I promise to do my best and really do a good job and be a good president.  And I want to thank Lisa Flanagan for being a super campaign manager. And I just want to say that I think Tracy would have made a great president too and that she really deserves a big hand. 
[59]Wow! Mr. McAllister! This is so wild. We came to celebrate my victory, and I can't believe it. Here, these are my parents. 
[60]This is great. 
[61]I never would have ran if it wasn't for Mr. M. 
[62]Yeah! 
[63]Why don't you guys go sit down, okay? I'll catch up in a minute? I want to talk to Mr. M. about some important stuff. 
[64]So, Mr. M,  I was starting to think about ideas for next year. I was thinking it would be cool to have, like a carnival.  With rides.  And, you know, it could be for, like. Muscular Dystrophy. 
[65]And on Halloween we could have a haunted house.  But a really good haunted house, not like those cheesy bad ones.  You know, more like the radio station ones.  This one would be really scary.  And for Homecoming -- well, you know how last year's theme was - 
[66]Oh, okay.  Yeah, sorry. 
[67]Just one more thing.  So, Mr. M., uh, do you think Tracy's going to be okay? I saw her face after the assembly, and I think she's taking it pretty hard. 
[68]Huh? 
[69]Senor presidente. Yo soy senor presidente... El grande presidente... 
[70]I don't know why, but finding out there was a mistake and I hadn't won the election after all didn't bother me that much. Winning had seemed kind of unreal anyway. I guess I should have voted for myself. Oh, well. 
[71]Is Tammy okay? 
[72]Senior year was great I Sure, I didn't get to play ball or be president, but I got elected homecoming king and prom king anyway. I got into Nebraska like I wanted and early-rushed Phi Delts. At the end of the year me and my buddies threw a hitching Mexican party down at the cement plant. Shit, that was a good party. That was a good party! 
[73]The only really bad thing about senior year was Lisa. Right before Christmas she dumped me. One minute she's totally in love with me and then boom she's going out with my football buddy Randy. 
[74]Sometimes I wonder what would've happened if I'd actually won the election.  Maybe my whole life would be different.  Like I might never have gone to Yosemite with Greg and Travis. 
[75]Or maybe I'd be dead. 
[76]Sure, Tracy. 
[77]Oh, yeah, sure. Hey Nolan, give my book to Tracy when you're done* 
[78]Thanks, Tracy. 
[79]Hey, Tracy I.. 
[80]Have a great summer.  And good luck at college.
dialogues.TAMMY:
[1]What? 
[2]If you could just get out of your head. 
[3]Don't you fucking knock? 
[4]Paul, get out! 
[5]You dumbshit! 
[6]You know how they say one day a big meteor might come and crash into the Earth and kill everybody? Well, I think that would be a good thing. 
[7]Lisa 
[8]Stop! Wait! 
[9]Where 're you going? 
[10]What...? 
[11]How can something that seems so true turn out to be such a lie? 
[12]I mean Lisa and I were destined to be together. It was so obvious. Of all the people on the planet who had ever lived, somehow we'd found each other. 
[13]Lisa... 
[14]I remember one time Lisa and I did an experiment with asparagus to see how long it takes your pee to smell. We peed a little every five minutes. 
[15]For her it took about fifteen minutes, and for me it was twenty. 
[16]Everyday I found some new way to tell Lisa I loved her. 
[17]But it just seemed like the closer we got, the more she pulled away. 
[18]What? 
[19]So? 
[20]I know. 
[21]I don't care. 
[22]What did I do to make her change? What's wrong with me? 
[23]Lisa. 
[24]Sometimes when I'm sad, I sit and watch the power station. 
[25]They say if you lie between two of the main wires, your body just evaporates. You become a gas.  I wonder what that would feel like. 
[26]I don ' t know what I did to make Lisa hate me so much, but somehow she decided to hurt roe. And she knew exactly what to do. 
[27]I had to do something.  I didn't know what, but I had to do something. 
[28]Who cares about this stupid election? 
[29]We all know it doesn't matter who gets elected president of Millard. You think it's going to change anything around here, make one single person happier or smarter or nicer? The only person it matters to is the one who gets elected. The same pathetic charade happens every year, and everyone makes the same pathetic promises just so they can put it on their transcripts to get into college.  So vote for me, because I don't even want to go to college, and I don't care, and as president I won't do anything.  The only promise I make is that if elected I will immediately dismantle the student government, so that none of us will ever have to sit through one of these stupid assemblies again! 
[30]0h don't vote for me I  Who cares? Don't vote at all!

[32]Hey -- I said lights I 
[33]What do you want? 
[34]Okay, Paul.  Thanks.  Thanks a lot. 
[35]Now could you leave me alone? 
[36]Sure, Paul.  No hard feelings. 
[37]You wanted to see me, Mr. M.? 
[38]Okay.  But is this about the posters? 
[39]Okay. Because I know who did it.  So.. I'll just be outside. 
[40]Well, this is hard for me, but I think it's important to be honest. Don't you? 
[41]I'm the one.  I did it.  I tore down Paul's posters. 
[42]I did it. 
[43]This weekend. 
[44]I don't know. Yesterday.  Sunday. 
[45]Door was open. 
[46]I don't know. All I know is I did it I 
[47]I have proof. 
[48]You don't know what it's like to grow up in the shadow of an older brother like Paul.  it's always Paul, Paul, Paul, Paul.  Never Tammy.  I'm only Paul's little sister.  You must be and I'm so troubled.  I hate him!  I hate him!  And I tore down his posters, It was a horrible, cowardly act, but I did it,.. I did it... l did it... And I'm not sorry... 
[49]Dad, I 
[50]Dear God, I know I don't believe in you, but since I'll be starting Catholic school soon, I thought I should practice.  Let's see... what do I want? I want people to be nicer to each other. I want Lisa to realize what a bitch she has been and feel really bad and apologize for how she hurt me and know how much I still love her.  In spite of everything, I still want Paul to win the election tomorrow, not that cunt Tracy. I also want a really expensive pair of leather pants... and someday I want to be really good friends with Madonna. Love, Tammy 
[51]I hate it. 
[52]Please, morn.  Please don't make me go to Sacred Heart.  I beg you. 
[53]Catholic school was great! 
[54]I mean, the teachers kind of sucked, and they were supposedly way more strict, but you could get away with murder. 
[55]The best thing about Sacred Heart was meeting Jennifer. 
[56]All those feelings I had for Lisa were just preparing me for the real thing. Jennifer and I are soul mates, and we're never, ever, ever going to be apart.

All other candidates are eligible.  Now please pay attention to a very important, uh, audio-visual presentation. Linda, who typed this thing?  I said I need all caps....

dialogues.DAVE:
[1]Her pussy gets so wet you can't believe it. 
[2]She's incredible.  Everything just gets soaked. 
[3]Foxy. . . Foxy. . . You know you're a cute little heartbreaker... Foxy... You know you're a sweet little love maker... 
[4]You know, Tracy... I don't know how to say this, but... 
[5]Well, I notice you don't seem to have any close friends at Millard. You seem to be kind of a loner. 
[6]I know.  I know its not by choice.  I just mean, well, being the kind of person you are, it must be really difficult to find someone you can talk to. 
[7]What kind of person? 
[8]Tracy, I've been watching you for going on two years now, and I think you are one of the most talented, hard-working, sensitive, attractive, brilliant students -- no, human beings -- I have ever met.  I mean, you're the real thing.  Special. 
[9]And I know sometimes people like you have to pay a price for their greatness, and that price is loneliness. 
[10]I don't know.  Maybe I'm wrong.  But it seems like you might need a friend. 
[11]Here, get down. 
[12]Look at you. 
[13]Look, Jim...  Okay.  I know it all seems crazy, and maybe it did start out, you know, for the... for the sex and the danger.  But now it's different.  Jim, what I'm trying to tell you is that Tracy and I are totally, totally in love. 
[14]Yeah, it's serious.  I mean she inspires me in ways Sherry never has. She even wants to read my novel. 
[15]That's the whole point. It's all in my head; it's right here.  I just got to get it out there. Tracy wants me to write it so she can read it.  It's beautiful. 
[16]You're not just jealous, are you?  I mean, we both used to talk about her 
[17]I don't need a lecture on ethics, Jim, okay?  I know what -- 
[18]Look, I appreciate your concern. I really do.  But like I said, I got it under control. 
[19]Tracy's Mom -- she doesn't understand. 
[20]But we're in love 
[21]Sherry   Sherry  Sheerrry. ...
dialogues.LARRY:
[1]Okay, Mr. M. 
[2]Well, I thought that... well, the way it always works is that SGA president does a count, then the SGA advisor, you know, for the two independent counts. 
[3]You have the key, Mr. McAllister. 
[4]Are you okay, Mr. M.? 
[5]Okay.  Yeah.  We know 
[6]I'm not supposed to tell. Not until you've counted too. We're each supposed to make an independent count. 
[7]I thought those were the rules, Mr. McAllister. If they've changed in any way -- 
[8]It's a squeaker, Mr. M. I've got Tracy by a vote. Just one vote. 
[9]Mr. M.? 
[10]Yeah? 
[11]No way I It doesn't make sense. 
[12]And 290 "disregards," right? 
[13]See, it doesn't add up. There are only 801 ballots but 803 people voted. Two votes are missing. Check the register. 
[14]But, they were there I counted 803 votes. 
[15]I didn't make a mistake. Every vote was there when you sac down 
[16]I'm telling you. Dr. Hendricks, every vote was accounted for. 
[17]But, Mr. M. - 
[18]You said I was a liar   You're the liar, you're the --

dialogues.DICK:
[1]Don't you smartass me!  Don't you dare smartass me!  You just shut your mouth I Now your mother and I have had a long talk with Halt Hendricks  --- we just got off the phone with him at home. You know, he doesn't want you back at Millard.  He's fed up with you.  Fed up!  And I don't blame him! 
[2]What? 
[3]You're going to Catholic school next year.  You're going to Sacred Heart. Maybe they'll straighten you out! 
[4]Yeah, say, apparently you've really come behind him, really helped him out there with the student council thing and all. 
[5]Having a problem with your eye there? 
[6]You ought to get that looked at. Shot of cortisone or something. 
[7]Anyway, we're awful sorry about what went on with our other one, you know, our Tammy. 
[8]Say, you're all alone,  why don't you join us? 
[9]All right.  Well, sure nice to meet you.
